G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment is liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 20.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Housing Court because the Premises are located in Boston (Jamaica Plain neighborhood), Suffolk County, Massachusetts, and the cause of action arose in this county.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all times relevant, Defendant has been the person entitled to rent and responsible for maintenance and repair obligations for the Premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including bu.raw_text: 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500 (structural elements and weather‑tightness) and 410.750 (conditions deemed to endanger health or safety)
105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including bu.proposition: The leak, moisture, and associated conditions materially impair the health, safety, and well‑being of Plaintiff and render the Premises not in compliance with the requirements of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: The presence of an active roof or ceiling leak and damp, musty conditions is a serious defect that Massachusetts courts have recognized as substantially interfering with tenant habitability and use.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurring/dissenting opinion discussing implied warranty of habitability and the State Sanitary Code in general terms. It does not describe or characterize any specific conditions such as roof or ceiling leaks or damp, musty conditions, nor does it label such conditions as serious defects that substantially interfere with habitability. Without factual discussion of leaks or dampness or a clear holding on that point, this citation does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The tenants defend principally on the following grounds stated in each of their similar answers: ‘that prior to her refusal to pay rent, plaintiff was in violation of the State Sanitary Code including . . . [various conditions allegedly violating specifically cited regulations of the Code] … and that said violations and conditions . . . render the apartment uninhabitable and such conditions continue today.’ The tenants’ allegations of specific violations of the Code were based on written inspection reports issued by appropriate housing inspectors describing those same conditions and concluding ‘that said violations may endanger or materially impair the health or safety, and the well-being of any tenant therein or persons occupying said property.’”}

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to the use and enjoyment of the leased premises without substantial interference from the landlord.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from serious interference with their tenancy and interference that substantially impairs the character and value of the leasehold. It then applies that standard to the plaintiffs’ inability to use common areas, confirming that such substantial interferences with use and enjoyment fall within the covenant’s protection. This directly aligns with the proposition stated.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to the use and enjoyment of the leased premises without substantial interference from the landlord.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court explicitly explains that “quiet enjoyment” in landlord-tenant law means the tenant’s right to be free from serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the leased premises, and applies that concept to repeated flooding caused by the landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions. It further notes that every tenancy carries an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right, and treats substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment (here, recurrent unsanitary flooding) as a violation of that covenant. This aligns directly with the proposition stated.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.” (385 Mass. at 102)

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.proposition: A landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 may arise where the landlord, after receiving notice, fails to remedy defective conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.support_reasoning: The case clearly addresses landlord liability for interference with quiet enjoyment, but it is decided under the common-law implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, not under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court discusses the landlord’s responsibility where, after notice, it fails to control conditions it has the power to remedy, but it never cites or applies § 14, so it cannot be proper authority for a proposition specifically about statutory liability under that section.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: A landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 may arise where the landlord, after receiving notice, fails to remedy defective conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reaffirms that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct, and identifies a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice as a paradigmatic violation where that failure interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. It states that where a landlord has notice or reason to know of a dangerous condition (here, lead paint) and fails to take appropriate corrective measures, § 14 liability may arise. This aligns with the proposition that, after notice, failure to remedy defective conditions that substantially interfere with use can create landlord liability under § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–02 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The existence of an ongoing leak, water damage, and unsanitary conditions that impair health or safety violates the State Sanitary Code and undermines the implied warranty of habitability recognized in Massachusetts law.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion certainly ties habitability to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and recognizes that a dwelling with substantial Code violations is not habitable, but this case is about loss of heat and hot water due to broken pipes, not an ongoing leak, water damage, or unsanitary conditions. The court’s holding concerns rent abatement and strict, fault-free liability under the implied warranty of habitability once the landlord has notice of defects that render the apartment uninhabitable; it does not specifically address leaks, water damage, or general unsanitary conditions impairing health or safety. Thus, it is supportive of the more general link between Sanitary Code violations and breach of the implied warranty, but not of the specific factual proposition stated.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The State Sanitary Code, not [landlords’] usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering.”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: The existence of an ongoing leak, water damage, and unsanitary conditions that impair health or safety violates the State Sanitary Code and undermines the implied warranty of habitability recognized in Massachusetts law.

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 747–49 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment may be breached by a landlord’s failure to timely repair known defective conditions that are within the landlord’s control and that substantially impair the value or habitability of the premises.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment in terms of landlord notice of defective conditions, the landlord’s control, and the duty to act to alleviate them, citing prior authority. It affirms that the covenant protects tenants from serious interferences and that a landlord who, after notice, at least negligently fails to alleviate such conditions can be liable. The court then finds no breach here precisely because the landlord promptly repaired the known defects, which implies that failure to timely repair such conditions could constitute a breach when they seriously interfere with the tenancy/habitability.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. … We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. … Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: In assessing damages for breach of quiet enjoyment, Massachusetts courts consider emotional distress and loss of use as compensable harms.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion construes G.L. c. 186, § 14 to allow recovery of “actual and consequential damages” for interference with quiet enjoyment, but in this case the court only identifies diminution in rental value and physical damage to personal property as the recoverable harms. The judge below specifically found that emotional distress was not proved, and the Supreme Judicial Court does not discuss emotional distress as a component of damages or otherwise indicate that loss of use or emotional distress are compensable under § 14. Thus, this case does not affirm that emotional distress and loss of use are compensable harms in quiet enjoyment cases.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove. When the actual damages exceed three months’ rent, however, § 14 plainly states that actual damages should be the measure of recovery. … It is clear that the plaintiff’s actual damages exceeded three times her monthly rent of $47. Her actual damages included the diminution of the value of the leasehold due to the breach of the implied warranty of habitability, as well as the damage to her personal property. … The judge found that a claim of emotional distress due to the BHA’s failure to repair the premises had not been proved.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
